resources.string: The diagnosis of malnutrition can be done using either the Mid Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC) or the Z-Score as main criteria, with or without the signs and symptoms listed in the "SIGNS & SYMPTOMS" section.
Mid Upper Arm Circumference (MUAC)\n MUAC is measured using a tailor\'s tape. The tape is placed midway between the elbow and the shoulder as shown below:\n

Normal: >12.5cm
 Moderate Malnutrition: 11.0 - 12.5cm
 Severe Malnutrition: <11.0cm

 OR

 Z-Score (Standard Deviation Score)
 	- Calculated using the child's most recent weight and height, with the height measured using a tape.
 	- A Z-Score between -1 and -2 indicates that your child is not malnourished.
 	- A Z-Score of less than -3 (i.e. -3 and -4) indicates severe malnutrition.

 You could determine if your child is malnourished by clicking the button below.
Fill above fields and click "Calculate" button
Sorry, we cannot calculate your z-score for the given height. Check the height again
This implies that your child is severely malnourished.
This implies that your child is not malnourished.
The following signs and symptoms would indicate your child is malnourished:\n \t- Pitting oedema on dorsum of foot (see images below)
Pitting oedema on dorsum of foot

- Ineffective feeding, that is, suckling difficulties observed for 15 to 20 minutes in children less than 6 months of age.
 	- Moon (round) face.
 	- Old man's face.
 	- Brown, scanty and brittle (easily broken) hair when compared to that of other family members.
 	- Loose and wrinkled skin (see image below).

- Distended (large) abdomen.
 	- Severe body weakness.
 	- Child not interested in surroundings.
 	- Muscle wasting, especially in buttocks.
 	- Visible severe wasting (see image below).
\t- Hypo or hyper pigmentation of skin (loss of normal skin color).\n \t- Diarrhoea.\n \t- Loss of appetite.
Encourage a balanced diet with protein-rich foods (e.g. beans, groundnuts) and calorie-rich foods (e.g rice, plantains, cocoyams, etc).\n Also encourage intake of vegetables.
Supplementary feeding; This would be by using local foods such as rice, beans and vegetables.\n Blended cereals such as corn-soya blend should also be given to the child. (Not soya beans)

For children less than 6 months
 	- Increase frequency and duration of breastfeeding if baby is breastfed.
 	- Babies not suffering from oedema should be given supplementary feeding using expressed breast milk. If that is not possible, artificial milk (tin milk) or F75 should be given either alone or together with expressed breast milk.
 Care of the malnourished child should continue at a health centre, so PLEASE SEE A DOCTOR as soon as possible.

 For children over 6 months
 The management of their severe malnutrition is divided in 2 phases: the Stabilization phase and the Rehabilitation phase.
 	i) Stabilization Phase
 		It is worth noting that by the end of the second day following the diagnosis, the child should have been taken to the nearest health care facility for proper medical care.
 		The stabilization is done using F75, a modified milk feed diet to treat the immediate complications of malnutrition.

 		How to prepare F75 at home:
 			- 35g of milk (about 8 table spoons)
 			- 70g of sugar (about 16 cubes)
 			- 20g of oil, Mayor or Azur (1 table spoon or 1 tea spoon)
 			- 35g of Bledina or Cerelac (about 8 table spoons)
 			- 10ml of multivitamins or 1 sachet of Genesvit junior
 			- Mix the above components in 1l of clean water.
 		NB:The F75 prepared as shown above should be stored in a fridge and placed in warm water before each feed.

 		How to give F75 to the child
 			Days 1-2:
 			Frequency(How often to feed): Two times each hour.
 			Quantity/kg per feed: 11ml
 			Quantity/kg per day: 130ml

 			Days 3-5:
 			Frequency(How often to feed): Three times each hour.
 			Quantity/kg per feed: 16ml
 			Quantity/kg per day: 130ml

 			Days 6 onwards:
 			Frequency(How often to feed): Four times each hour.
 			Quantity/kg per feed: 22ml
 			Quantity/kg per day: 130ml

 			*Quantity/kg = corresponding figure for day x weight of child in kg

 		Feed the child from a cup or bowl using a spoon, or better still, a syringe (Without the needle).

 		Monitoring
 			- Always record amount of feed given and leftover.
 			- Take note if child vomits.
 			- Check for increased respiratory rate, that is, child breathes faster than normal. If it is the case, you should see a doctor.
 			- How many times does the child pass stool in a day? Are the stools soft, watery or normal?
 			- Check for signs of improvement such as:
 				* Return of appetite
 				* Most or all of oedema (swelling) is gone

 	ii) Rehabilitation Phase
 		NB: The doctor will inform parents when the child is ready to begin the rehabilitation phase.
 		The rehabilitation phase is done using diluted F100.

 		How to prepare diluted F100 at home:
 			- 110g of milk (about twenty four and a half table spoons)
 			- 50g of sugar (about eleven and a half cubes)
 			- About 2 table spoons of oil, Mayor or Azur
 			- 1 sachet of Genesvit junior
 			- Mix all the above in 1l of water, then add 300ml of water.

 		NB: The F100 prepared as shown above should be stored in a fridge and placed in warm water before each feed.

 Other Aspects of Management
 Milk feeds aside (F75 and F100), the child also needs:
 	- Lots of tenderness, love and care.
 	- A cheerful/happy environment.
 	- 5 to 30 minutes of play time each day.

 A Malnourished Child with Diarrhoea
 	- If a malnourished child has diarrhoea, they are considered to have some (moderate) dehydration.
 	- This is treated using ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for the Malnourished) at a hospital or health centre. PLEASE SEE A DOCTOR!!!
Passage of greater than 3 loose stools in a day, with no blood in the stools.

All children with diarrhoea should be assessed and classified as either having severe dehydration, some (moderate) dehydration, or no (mild) dehydration.

 Severe Dehydration
 Characterised by at least two of the following:
 - Severe body weakness (lethargy) or unconsciousness
 - Sunken eyes
 - Unable to drink or drinks poorly
 - After pinching the skin, it returns to normal very slowly (two seconds or more)

 Some (Moderate) Dehydration
 Characterised by at least two of the following:
 - Restlessness or irritability - Sunken eyes - Drinks eagerly; thirsty - After pinching the skin, it returns to normal slowly

 No (Mild) Dehydration
 Not enough signs to classify as some dehydration or severe dehydration.

Treatment is given at home

 How to prepare Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) at home: In 1 litre of clean water, add 8 cubes of sugar + 1 teaspoon of salt + 1 lemon (squeezed), then mix properly so that the sugar and salt dissolve.

 The treatment at home should follow the active rules listed below:
 	- Continue feeding
 	- Give extra fluids
 	- Give zinc supplements
 	- When to go to the hospital or health centre

 I.	Continue Feeding
 - If the child is breastfed, feed more frequently or longer.
 - If exclusively breastfed, give ORS or clean water in addition to breast milk.

 II.	Give Extra Fluids
 - If not exclusively breastfed, give either ORS or CLEAN WATER.
 - To prevent dehydration, give as much fluid as the child will take, that is,
 		* Less than 2 years: 50 - 100ml after every loose stool
 		* Greater than 2 years: 100 - 200ml after every loose stool
 - Give small sips from a cup. If the child vomits, wait 10 minutes then continue more slowly. Continue administering extra fluids till diarrhoea reduces.
 - Mother should have two extra packets of ORS or already locally prepared ORS at home.

 III.	Give Zinc Supplements
 Give zinc supplements as follows:
 	* Less than 6 months: 1/2 tablet (10mg) per day for 10 - 14 days.
 	* Greater than 6 months: 1 tablet (20mg) per day for 10 - 14 days.
 Dissolve the zinc tablet in breast milk, clean water or ORS before administering to the child.

 IV.	 When to go to the Hospital or Health Centre
 - If the child gets sicker, becomes unable to drink or breastfeed, develops a fever, or begins having blood in their stool, take the child to a hospital or health centre as soon as possible.
 - If there is no improvement after 5 days, take the child to a hospital or health centre.

 Administer the same treatment if the child suffers from similar diarrhoea again.

Could be treated at home if the following steps are well followed

 What do you use? Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS). This is sold in packets at the hospital, health centre or pharmacy. ORS can also be made at home.

 How to prepare ORS at home: In 1 litre of clean water, add 8 cubes of sugar + 1 teaspoon of salt + 1 lemon (squeezed), then mix properly so that the sugar and salt dissolve.

 **Missing table**

 - If the child wants more ORS than is prescribed above, feel free to give more.
 - Give frequent sips from a cup. If the child vomits, wait 10 minutes then continue, but more slowly.
 - Continue breastfeeding whenever the child wants.
 - Give zinc supplements as follows:
 	* Less than 6 months: 1/2 tablet (10mg) per day for 10 - 14 days.
 	* Greater than 6 months: 1 tablet (20mg) per day for 10 - 14 days.
 	Dissolve the zinc tablet in breast milk, clean water or ORS before administering to the child.

 - If the child gets sicker, becomes unable to drink or breastfeed, develops a fever, or begins having blood in their stool, take the child to a hospital or health centre as soon as possible.
 - If there is no improvement after 5 days, take the child to a hospital or health centre.

 Administer the same treatment if the child suffers from similar diarrhoea again.

Should be treated at a hospital or health centre.

 Fluids to use:
 Isotonic fluids like Ringer\’s lactate solution (Hartmann\’s solution) and Normal Saline solution (0.9% NaCl).

 Do not use the following:
 5% glucose (dextrose) or 0.18 Saline with 5% dextrose solution.
 They increase the risk of hyponatraemia which can in turn cause cerebral oedema.
Persistent diarrhoea is defined as diarrhoea with or without blood in the stool which begins acutely, lasting 14 days or more.
This is diarrhoea lasting 14 days or more with no signs of dehydration and no severe malnutrition.

- Give treatment according to treatment Plan A (No (Mild) Dehydration).
 - ORS is effective for most children with persistent diarrhoea. However, if the child does not tolerate ORS (i.e. there is an increase in stool volume, thirst or worsening of signs of dehydration), such children should be given treatment at a hospital or health centre until ORS can be tolerated without worsening of the diarrhoea.
 - Antibiotics treatment is NOT NECESSARY unless there is evidence of an intestinal or non intestinal infection.

 Feeding
 	- Reduce the amount of milk in the child's diet temporarily.
 	- Continue breastfeeding more often and longer by day and night.
 	- If the child is taking some other form of milk, replace animal milk with fermented milk like yogurt which contains less lactose and is well tolerated.
 	- If the above mentioned replacement is not possible, reduce animal milk to a maximum of 50ml/kg (i.e. 50 x child's weight in kg) in 24 hours.
 	- Formula-fed children that are older than 4 months should start taking in solid foods.
 	- Give frequent small feeds, at least 6 times per day.

 Follow Up
 	- Take the child back to the hospital or health centre after 5 days at most if the diarrhoea worsens or other problems develop.
 	- Check for signs of dehydration and the child's body temperature to ensure there is no fever.
 	- If the child has gained weight and has less than 3 loose stools per day, they may resume the normal diet for their age.
Dysentery is defined as loose stools containing blood.\n

A child with dysentery will have some or all of the following signs:
 	- Abdominal pain
 	- Fever
 	- Severe body weakness
 	- Dehydration

Take the child to a hospital or health centre as soon as possible.

 Follow Up
 Two days after starting the treatment at the hospital or health centre, check for signs of improvement such as:
 	- No fever
 	- Fewer stools with less blood
 	- Improved appetite

 If there is no improvement, return to the hospital.

 Treat for dehydration depending on the level of dehydration.

 Feeding
 Less than 6 months
 	- Continue breastfeeding throughout the illness, but do so more frequently than usual.

 Over 6 months
 	- They should receive their normal meals.
 	- Encourage the child to eat, and allow the child to select preferred foods.
This is diarrhoea lasting 14 days or more, with signs of some dehydration or severe dehydration.

- Take the child to the hospital
 - Child should be assessed and treated according to Plan B (Some Dehydration) or Plan C (Severe Dehydration) depending on the level of dehydration
 - ORS is effective for most children with persistent diarrhoea. However, if the child does not tolerate ORS (i.e. there is an increase in stool volume, thirst or worsening of signs of dehydration), such children should be given treatment at a hospital or health centre until ORS can be tolerated without worsening of the diarrhoea.
 - Antibiotics treatment is NOT NECESSARY unless there is evidence of an intestinal or non intestinal infection.

 Feeding
 Children less than 6 months
 	- Breastfeeding should be continued for as often and long as the child wants.
 	- Other foods should not be given for as long as 4 to 6 hours to allow for rehydration to be done, depending on the level of dehydration.

 Children over 6 months
 	- Restart feeding as soon as the child can eat. Feed the child at least 6 times a day to ensure they meet adequate energy requirements.

 Follow Up
 Check the following to ensure that the child is improving:
 	- Weight gain: Increase in weight for 3 consecutive days shows favourable response to treatment.
 	- Temperature: Absence of fever shows appropriate response to treatment.
 	- Number of stools per day: Passage of less than 3 loose stools per day shows favourable response to treatment.
 	- Food taken in: Increase in quantity of food taken in by the child shows favourable response to treatment.

- This section will focus on diagnosis and prevention of mother to child transmission (PMTCT) of HIV as 90% of children infected with HIV get it from their mothers.

 - In 2012, there were still an estimated 260000 new infections in children.

 - It is however possible to have healthy HIV negative children from HIV positive mothers. HIV/AIDS does not prevent you from having children.

 - Without treatment, there is a 15-45% chance of the infection getting to your baby. With treatment, this value goes below 5%.

 - Therefore there is the need on the part of mothers and health care practitioners to know and implement the appropriate information to reduce mother to child transmission (MTCT) values to the minimum.

At your booking visit (1st ANC visit) you will be given a series of tests to do including the HIV test. You will be counselled prior to and after the release of the test results.

 i. If you test negative for HIV, it is important that you stay negative. If you have unprotected sex, and/or share needles and syringes, then test again.

 ii. If you test positive for HIV, pay careful attention during your counselling about your health. You will be given a series of tests to do (pre-therapeutic work up) after which you should report to your doctor with the results.
 - Then move to STEP TWO.

International guidelines by the World Health organisation (WHO) option B+ demand that you should be placed on treatment as soon as you are diagnosed. You should adhere to this treatment for life. You should take the drugs at a particular time of the day at your convenience and for the rest of your life. If complications occur, please SEE YOUR DOCTOR for assessment and maybe a change of the drugs. Do not stop the drugs without informing your doctor.

 NB:
 Benefits of Antiretrovirals:
 - Keep you strong and healthy
 - Make you less infectious
 - Protect your baby

 Things to avoid:
 - Smoking
 - Alcohol

When you get into labour at the hospital, inform the doctor or midwife about your HIV status so that dispositions can be taken to minimise chances of transmission to your baby. You can deliver vaginally, as being HIV positive does not prevent this. However, caesarean delivery will be the safest and fastest mode of delivery for you.\n\n The decision on the route of delivery will be made based on the situations surrounding delivery, your doctor’s opinion and your consent.

i.	Feeding method depends on availability of resources.
 		- If the resources are available, bottle feeding is the gold standard. Seek appropriate counselling on how this is done and hygiene should be prioritised.
 		- However if the resources are not available, exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months should be done.
 		- Mixed feeding should be avoided.

 ii.	- If you decide to breastfeed, your child should be given Nevirapine once a day from birth until 1 week after you stop breastfeeding.
 		- If you decide not to breastfeed, your child should receive Nevirapine once a day from birth until 6 weeks of age.

The age at which your baby can be tested for HIV depends on the kind of test done and the method of feeding.

 1. PCR TEST
 If the baby is breastfeeding: PCR test can be done from age 1 month and repeated 3 months after the child stops breastfeeding to ensure the child is negative.
 If the child is not breastfeeding: PCR test can be done from age 1 month and repeated when the child is 4 months old to confirm the child is negative.
 If the child is on Nevirapine: PCR test can be done from age 1 month and should be repeated 2-4 weeks after Nevirapine is stopped.

 2. ANTIBODY TEST
 This test should be done when the child is at least 18 months old.
 - If the child tests negative, he/she is negative.
 - If the child tests positive, he/she is positive.
- If your baby tests negative, it is important that your baby stays that way.\n\n - If your baby tests positive, he/she should be placed on treatment as soon as possible.

- Hepatitis B is the inflammation of the liver as a result of infection from hepatitis B virus. It may or may not present itself with symptoms such as fever, loss of appetite, vomiting, diarrhoea, yellowing of the eyes, tiredness, body pains, dark urine and pale-coloured stool.

 - This virus can be transmitted through contact with infected blood, semen, vaginal secretions and, to a lesser extent, saliva.

 - Your immune system can protect you from hepatitis B infection within a few months even without treatment. However 5% of people continue carrying the virus. This leads to damages to your liver in the long run.

 - 10-20% of women who are Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg) positive will transmit the infection to their babies without appropriate treatment of the mother and child.

At your booking visit (1st ANC visit), among the tests requested to be done on you will be Hepatitis B surface antigen (HBsAg).

 i. If you test negative, it is important you stay that way.

 ii. If you test positive, you will be directed to a doctor who will run a test to check for the level of the virus in your blood. This is called the viral load.

i. If the viral load is low, your doctor will surely not put you on treatment immediately.

 ii. If the viral load is high you may be offered treatment either with lamivudine or tenofovir. Treatment will often start in the 3rd trimester of pregnancy (i.e. last 3 months of your pregnancy) and continue to the 12th week after delivery, and could even extend beyond this date depending on your response to the treatment and the evaluation from your doctor.

 NB: If you have already been diagnosed and placed on treatment prior to your pregnancy, inform your doctor about your treatment to ensure the safety of your baby.

- When you get into labour, inform the doctor or midwife of your hepatitis B status so that the necessary precautions can be taken to ensure your baby’s safety.\n\n - You can deliver vaginally, given that being hepatitis B positive doesn’t prevent you from doing so.

Vaccination
 - At birth, your baby should receive the Hepatitis B vaccine.
 - This vaccine should be followed up by an injection with antibodies against Hepatitis B.
 - Your baby will need another vaccine at ages 1 month, 2 months and 1 year. A booster is recommended for these vaccines at the age of 5 years.

* It is important for your baby to receive the vaccines because 9 out of 10 babies who get infected from their mothers go on to have chronic hepatitis.
 * When you go for routine vaccination according to the Expanded Program for Immunisation, inform the nurse of your status, emphasizing that your child is already receiving hepatitis vaccines.

 Feeding

It is safe for you to breastfeed your baby as long as he/she is receiving his/her vaccines.

Your baby should have a blood test around his/her 1st birthday to check if all the viruses are gone.

 i. If your baby tests negative, it is important he/she stays that way.

 ii. If your baby tests positive, you should see a doctor for a more detailed evaluation of your child.

Adequate nutrition: Pregnant women are encouraged to eat foods rich in protein, vitamins, iron and calcium.

 Clothing: Should be free, light and hanging from shoulders. Avoid high heels, shoes with thin soles, belts and corsets.

 Good Hygiene: The mouth and breasts should be kept very clean throughout pregnancy and after delivery.

 Sexual activity: To be avoided by pregnant women with threatened abortion, preterm labour or antepartum hemorrhage.

 Travelling: It is allowed when comfortable. For patients with a history of antepartum hemorrhage or preterm labour, it is better to avoid travelling.

 Weight Gain: 1 - 2kg in the first trimester (first three months) of pregnancy, and an average weight gain of 0.4kg/week from 20 weeks onwards.

 Baths: Showers are preferable over tub baths. No vaginal douches are allowed.

 Exercise: Exercises should be mild. Walking should be the preferred option. House work, if it is not too tiring, is allowed.

 Rest and Sleep: Rest eight hours at night and two hours in the afternoon. Increase rest sleep hours towards term.

 Drugs: Avoid all unnecessary drugs during pregnancy. Minor should be managed without the use of drugs whenever possible, by reassuring the patient.

 Smoking and Alcohol Consumption: These should NOT be attempted during pregnancy given that they cause a lot of complications.

 Irradiation: Avoid exposure to irradiation because of its teratogenic effect on the fetus.

- Nausea and vomiting
 - Heart burn
 - Phyalism (excessive salivation)
 - Constipation
 - Hemorrhoids and varicose veins
 - Swelling of feet
 - Leg cramps
 - Excessive colorless, odorless vaginal discharge not associated with burning sensations or itches.
 - Back ache

Certain pregnancies are classified as HIGH risk because they have a greater probability of jeopardizing maternal and fetal welfare. These conditions require a keener follow up during pregnancy. They include:
 	- Early first pregnancy, less than 18 years old.
 	- Late first pregnancy, more than 35 years old.
 	- Long duration of marriage with infertility and use of ovulatory drugs.
 	- Women who have had 5 or more deliveries.
 	- Previous intrauterine death or neonatal death.
 	- Previous fetal malformation.
 	- Previous second trimester (fourth to sixth months of pregnancy) abortion or preterm labour.
 	- Recurrent first trimester (first to third months of pregnancy) abortions.
 	- Previous caesarian delivery.
 	- Previous postpartum hemorrhage.
 	- Past history of hypertension, heart disease or murmur.
 	- Chronic illnesses e.g. cancer, diabetes.
 	- Previous surgery to uterus, including cervical cerclages.
 	- Maternal height less than 1.50m.

 Women who fall into any of these groups should inform their attending physicians about this so that special attention can be shown to them or they could be referred to higher levels of health for follow up.

Pregnant women should seek IMMEDIATE care if they experience any of the following symptoms or signs:
 	- Vaginal bleeding, no matter how small it is.
 	- Severe swelling (of lower limbs, face or fingers).
 	- Spontaneous escape of fluid from the Vagina.
 	- Abnormal gain or loss of weight.
 	- Decrease or cessation of fetal movements.
 	- Severe headache.
 	- Epigastric pain.
 	- Fever.
 	- Persistent vomiting.
When was the last time you had your menses?
Your expected date of delivery (EDD) should be displayed here.
Your expected date of delivery is:\n
Don\'t forget your checkup next week
You are in the first trimester of pregnancy. Next week you need to go for your Antenatal Clinic.

Antenatal Clinic (ANC) refers to the continuous care given to mothers and their unborn babies throughout the pregnancy period.

 ANC provides women and their families with appropriate information and advice for a healthy pregnancy, safe delivery, and recovery after delivery.
 It also includes care of the newborn, promotion of early, exclusive breastfeeding, and assistance with deciding on future pregnancies (family planning) in order to improve pregnancy outcomes.

 An effective ANC package depends on competent health care providers in a well-equipped functioning health system, which can provide referral services and has laboratory support.

The World Health Organization (WHO) now recommends each pregnant woman to have at least FOUR focused antenatal care visits before delivery of the baby.

 The goals and activities of ANC are summarized in each of the sections below:

FIRST ANC VISIT (8 - 12 weeks):

 Aim:
 	- Confirm pregnancy and calculate estimated date of delivery (EDD).
 	- Classify women for basic ANC (four visits) or more specialized care.
 	- Screen, treat and give preventive measures for diseases.
 	- Develop a birth and emergency plan.
 	- Advise and counsel pregnant women.

 Screening:
 	- Family/personal past history
 	- Weight
 	- Blood pressure
 	- Anemia
 	- Fundal height

 Tests:
 	- Haemoglobin
 	- Blood/Rhesus group
 	- Veneral disease screening
 	- Hepatitis B & C/toxoplasmosis/rubella/HIV tests
 	- Urine analysis
 	- Stool analysis
 	- Ultrasound

 Treatment:
 	- Commence HIV treatment if positive.
 	- Treat infections/diseases if indicated.
 	- Continue management of preexisting/de novo conditions (e.g. diabetes, hypertension)

 Preventive measures for diseases:
 	- Tetanus toxoid
 	- Iron and folate supplements

 Health education, advice and counseling:
 	- Self-care
 	- Alcohol and tobacco use
 	- Nutrition
 	- Safe sex
 	- Rest
 	- Sleeping under ITN
 	- Birth and emergency plan

SECOND ANC VISIT (22 - 24 weeks):

 Aim:
 	- Assess maternal and fetal well-being.
 	- Exclude PIH and anaemia.
 	- Give preventive measures for diseases.
 	- Review and modify birth and emergency plan.
 	- Advise and counsel.

 Screening:
 	- Weight
 	- Blood pressure
 	- Anemia
 	- Fundal height

 Tests:
 	- Urine analysis
 	- Screen for diabetes mellitus

 Treatment:
 	- Commence HIV treatment if positive.
 	- Treat infections/diseases if indicated.
 	- Continue management of preexisting/de novo conditions (e.g diabetes, hypertension)

 Preventive measures for diseases:
 	- Tetanus toxoid
 	- Iron and folate supplements
 	- IPTp
 	- ARV

 Health education, advice and counseling
 	- Birth and emergency plan.
 	- Reinforcement of previous advice.

THIRD ANC VISIT (32 weeks):

 Aim:
 	- Assess maternal and fetal well-being.
 	- Exclude PIH, anaemia and multiple pregnancies.
 	- Give preventive measures for diseases.
 	- Review and modify birth and emergency plan.
 	- Advise and counsel.

 Screening:
 	- Weight
 	- Blood pressure
 	- Anaemia
 	- Fundal height

 Tests:
 	- Urine analysis
 	- Ultrasound

 Treatment:
 	- Commence HIV treatment if positive.
 	- Treat infections/diseases if indicated.
 	- Continue management of preexisting/de novo conditions (e.g. diabetes, hypertension).

 Preventive measures for diseases:
 	- Iron and folate supplements.
 	- IPTp
 	- ARV

 Health education, advice and counseling:
 	- Birth and emergency plan.
 	- Infant feeding.
 	- Postpartum/postnatal care.
 	- Pregnancy spacing.
 	- Reinforcement of previous advice.

FOURTH VISIT (36 weeks):

 Aim:
 	- Assess maternal and fetal well-being.
 	- Exclude PIH, anaemia, multiple pregnancies and malpresentation.
 	- Give preventive measures for diseases.
 	- Review and modify birth and emergency plan.
 	- Advise and counsel.

 Screening:
 	- Weight
 	- Blood pressure
 	- Anaemia
 	- Fundal height

 Tests:
 	- Urine analysis
 	- Ultrasound

 Treatment:
 	- Commence HIV treatment if positive.
 	- Treat infections/diseases if indicated.
 	- Continue management of preexisting/de novo conditions (e.g. diabetes, hypertension).
 	- Rotation/referral for rotation of fetus if in breech.

 Preventive measures for diseases:
 	- Iron and folate supplements.
 	- ARV

 Health education, advice and counseling:
 	- Birth and emergency plan.
 	- Infant feeding.
 	- Postpartum/postnatal care.
 	- Pregnancy spacing.
 	- Reinforcement of previous advice.
